timeline.headline: Brief History
timeline.text: Apache Spark is a fast and general engine for large-scale data processing.

date.headline: Google pusblishes The Google File System
date.text: Sanjay Ghemawat, Howard Gobioff, and Shun-Tak Leung (Google)

date.headline: Google publishes MapReduce: Simplified Data Processing on Large Clusters
Hadoop is created
date.text: Hadoop was created by Doug Cutting and Mike Cafarella in 2006. Cutting, who was working at Yahoo! at the time, named it after his son's toy elephant. It was originally developed to support distribution for the Nutch search engine project. Facebook, Twitter, eBay quickly follow.

date.headline: Hive brings SQL to Hadoop
date.text: Hive is developed at Facebook to break the entry barrier of working with Hadoop Map Reduce. They implement the shortest path to translate SQL into Map Reduce jobs. It is now used by many more and developed by other companies too, such as Netflix.

date.headline: Mahout brings ML to Hadoop
date.text: Mahout brings Machine Learning algorithms to the Hadoop ecosystem.

date.headline: Giraph brings Graph processing to Hadoop
date.text: Based on another Google paper about its own graph processing system called Pregel, Giraph brings graph analysis algorithms to the Hadoop ecosystem.

date.headline: Spark starts as research project
date.text: Spark started as a research project in the AMPLab at UC-Berkeley. It was the main topic of Matei Zaharia's PhD thesis.

asset.caption: University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States

date.headline: Spark is open sourced
date.text: 1st version of Spark was 1,600 lines of codes and could run Wikipedia demo: Interactively searching through Wikipedia within seconds (30 GB uncompressed).

date.headline: AMPLab announces Berkeley Data Analytics Stack
date.text: AMPLab started to develop higher-level components on Spark: Spark Streaming, MLib, GraphX, Spark SQL. These and other components are often referred to as the Berkeley Data Analytics Stack (BDAS)

date.headline: RIA starts using Spark
date.text: We start exploring Spark for our Big Data platform.

date.headline: Spark's adoption increases
date.text:
255 contibutors

50 companies contributing

175,000 lines of codes

Spark sorted 1 PB of data (10 trillion records) on 190 machines in under 4 hours.

This PB time beats previously reported results based on Hadoop MapReduce (16 hours on 3800 machines).

asset.media: “The fastest engine for sorting a petabyte”
